title: Introduction
publication_title: Whistler Paintings and Drawings at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body"> IntroductionJay A. Clarke  
Rothman Family Curator  
Prints and DrawingsSarah Kelly Oehler  
Field-McCormick Chair and Curator  
Arts of the AmericasWe are delighted to present Whistler Paintings and Drawings at the Art Institute of Chicago, the museum’s fifteenth digital scholarly publication. This exploration of James McNeill Whistler’s paintings and drawings follows on the heels of an extensive collaborative project between the Art Institute of Chicago, the University of Glasgow, and the Freer Gallery of Art to catalogue his etchings, the results of which were published online in 2012. The launch of the present digital publication also coincides with the imminent rerelease of the catalogue raisonné The Lithographs of James McNeill Whistler, first published by the Art Institute in 1998 and soon to be reissued as a digital catalogue to ensure this crucial resource is available free of charge to scholars worldwide. We recognized that an in-depth study of the paintings and drawings in the Art Institute’s collection would complement these earlier, print-focused publications, thus offering readers a fuller understanding of Whistler’s work as seen through the museum’s robust holdings. Generous support by the Lunder Foundation for the Lunder Consortium for Whistler Studies has made this work possible.

The nearly fifty paintings and drawings included in this catalogue span the full range of Whistler’s career, from early drawings to late-career paintings. They also demonstrate his skill in a variety of media—among them chalk, graphite, ink, oil paint, pastel, and watercolor—and subject matter. The thirty-four catalogue entries enable the reader to understand the breadth of this versatile artist’s production and how to situate each work within art history. Technical reports accompanying many of the entries afford scholars the opportunity to delve deeper into his materials and methods. Whistler famously declared in his “Ten O’Clock Lecture” (1885), “Nature contains the elements of color and form of all pictures—as the keyboard contains the notes of all music—but the artist is born to pick, and choose, and group with science, these elements, that the result may be beautiful.” It seems only fitting that art historical study and conservation science should align in this catalogue to reveal a more comprehensive picture of Whistler’s science of art.

The three essays in this publication further explore varying aspects of Whistler’s art, science, and history. Sarah Kelly Oehler connects the surprising fact of Whistler’s familial connections in Chicago to the early establishment of his reputation in the city. Stephanie L. Strother considers the sheer variety of Whistler’s art, as seen through the lens of the museum’s collection, to consider his art as a “symphony with many notes.” Finally, Kimberley Muir investigates the very foundations of his paintings, using the latest scientific techniques to illuminate how Whistler’s choices of ground layers impacted the aesthetics of his art.

This catalogue also enables readers to examine Whistler’s works on their own, through high-resolution photography that encourages close looking. Digital overlays of conservation imaging of the paintings further augment the catalogue’s rich visual resources, providing insight into his working methods. We have included extensive comparative illustrations, a glossary of art historical and conservation terms, and links to references published online. This catalogue does not, however, feature exhibition and publication histories; recognizing that this research is never finished, the best repository for that information remains the individual object pages on the Art Institute’s website.

Since Whistler’s lifetime, the artist and his works have been the subject of countless studies, including many produced by the Art Institute of Chicago. But it is our hope that with this digital catalogue—a publication that addresses Whistler’s art in terms both local and global, art historical and scientific—we can reach a broader audience than ever before, inspiring them with the ability to see Whistler with new eyes.
